captions.text: Hey guys, ChrisFix here
and today I want to explain to you why
you should not use bug spray on your headlights to make them clear again.
You might have seen something like this, where you use bug spray with DEET in it
in this case, 25%
and you spray it on the headlight to remove the haze
First off, you do not want to spray this directly onto the headlight
you have all your paint and rubber trim here that can get damaged if you do that
you want to spray the bug spray onto the towel
[Aerosol Spray Sound]
The reason why the headlight is getting so clear is because the DEET
actually melts the plastic on the headlight
and the oils that are in the spray
fill the pores of the headlight plastic as well
you can see all of the oxidation and residue that comes off the headlight
with the DEET it does a really good job of cleaning it off
but that is because it is dissolving the plastic
and if you dont believe me that it is dissolving the plastic
the lens is actually tacky
you can see my finger sticking to it
and you can actually see my fingerprint
that it leaves on here. That is because the plastic is dissolved
so it is a tacky surface
Now you can see this looks amazing and I wish it could stay like this
but it wont
I wanted to test the long term clarity of using bug spray
but just 2 days later
the headlight started getting hazy again.
although this might work to get your headlights clear for am automotive inspection
so you can pass inspection... it wont last
there are other better methods that you can use
I dont recommend using bug spray to clean your headlights
because the DEET will continue to dissolve the plastic until it washes off
and then as it rains, it will wash off
down onto your bumper, onto your paint
and it will damage the clear coat on your paint
and it will damage your bumper if you have plastic bumpers
Now I am not saying that this doesn't have its applications
sure, in some situations, this might be useful
I would try bug spray as a last resort method
to try and clean your headlights before you replace them
but there are other methods that work just as well
and they pose less of a risk for your paint and plastic and everything
because these other methods do not dissolve plastic
but if you do want to try this method
like I said, make sure you spray it on a paper towel first
and then wipe the paper towel on the lens
also, do not let the DEET stay on your headlight
give it about 10 minutes to do its thing
but then clean it off very good, multiple times, to prevent damage
I also tried this out on my truck's headlights since I need to replace them anyway
you can see this headlight had a problem with a lot of cracking
and this is where the bug spray worked pretty well
and I would actually consider it
because this headlight is bad otherwise
so as a final note
Does bug spray actually make your headlights clear?
Yes it does
Does it do it in an effective way?
I do not think so
In less than a month your headlights are going to get dull again
and not only that,
you are risking damage to your paint's clear coat
and the plastic bumper that this might get on
I'd like you guys to comment below if you have tried this before
or what methods you have tried before
and how long they lasted
I am sure there will be many people reading the comments
and I am sure they would love to hear what you had to say
If you want a home remedy that is safer to use than the bug spray
and will give you similar results
try using toothpaste
I made a video using toothpaste
to clean the headlights and make them clear again
so you can see the results
which will surprise you
to get to that video you can click on the screen
or you can click on the link in the description below
but before you do that
remember to share this with your friends
so they do not damage their headlights or their paint
also give the video a thumbs up
and consider subscribing for more helpful videos like this

title: Using Bug Spray to Clean Headlights (WARNING!!!)

comments.text:
I work at a shop, and some of my buddys have been telling me this stuff 
works, and I've been hesitant to try it, but they have convinced me to use 
transmission fluid to do it so i don't know what I've been waiting for 
haha. But transmission fluid does actually help, but it doesn't last but a 
few weeks, and needs to be regularly coated. it also damages paint if not 
careful.﻿
comments.author: WhipLash10skaters

comments.text:
+WhipLash10skaters Eventually tranny fluid will ruin headlights so be 
careful! Check this out instead: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UEJbKLZ7RmM&lc
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: After it drys can you spray it with clear coat???﻿
comments.author: countryside

comments.text:
+countryside you do not want the lens to be smooth and the bug spray will 
cause the clear coat to bubble if you didnt get all of it off. You want to 
have scratches and follow the 400-600-2000 exactly like in this video. The 
600 grit puts deep enough scratches into the surface of the lens while the 
2000 light sand, cuts any surface roughness off. This allows for the clear 
coat to adhere properly so it wont peel in a year. If you make it smooth, 
the clear coat wont grab onto anything and it will peel. You can also have 
a problem with the paint running.
comments.author: ChrisFix

I used bug spray on my cavaliers headlights last thanksgiving. I didnt use 
Deep Woods Off. I used the Wal Mart counter part Repel. I had no stickiness 
and my headlights are still clear. All i did different was to buff the 
spray off with a couple of clean paper towels. You say to not use bug spray 
but to instead use toothpaste. I dont understand your logic on this because 
toothpaste scratches the lens and it might last a month and you have to 
reapply again. The more you do the toothpaste method the more scratches on 
the lens. In the long run your just putting a nail in the coffin because 
over time the scratches will be the fog on the lens.﻿

comments.text:
Start with 1500 wet-or-dry sandpaper. Sand the lights smooth. Then buff 
them with any brand of rubbing compound. If you use an electric buffer, the 
whole operation for two headlights should take less than 15 minutes. This 
method is a little harder than bug spray, but it's cheap, easy, and doesn't 
damage anything. It lasts for well over a year. We use this method on 
almost all of our trade-in cars and it makes them look 100% better than 
when they arrived at our dealership.﻿

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
I've used bug spray to restore headlights for not just myself but also for 
friends and family. I use windex to clean the headlight first, then two 
passes with the bug spray, then use windex again to make sure all the bug 
spray is cleaned off. After that I use Meguiars PlastX to polish and seal 
the headlight. I've never had an issue with harming the paint on any 
vehicle and it takes about 6-8 months for the headlights on any of the 
vehicles I've done to start looking only slightly oxidized again. 
http://i.imgur.com/iLLSBJn.jpg  Here is a pic of a headlight I restored on 
a 2006 Toyota Corolla using this method.﻿

+Joseph Williams You do not want the lens to be smooth and the bug spray 
will cause the clear coat to bubble if you didnt get all of it off. You 
want to have scratches and follow the 400-600-2000 exactly like in this 
video. The 600 grit puts deep enough scratches into the surface of the lens 
while the 2000 light sand, cuts any surface roughness off. This allows for 
the clear coat to adhere properly so it wont peel in a year. If you make it 
smooth, the clear coat wont grab onto anything and it will peel. You can 
also have a problem with the paint running.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
I have tried all the tricks in the book to clean headlights on my last car. 
I got so fed up I was seriously about to buy another pair of lights until I 
realized 3M makes a kit to clean headlights the right way. It comes with 
several different sandpaper grits and polish. You sand off the layer of dry 
rotted plastic and polish it. They came out brand new again! Seriously. 
Save your frustration and buy a kit actually made to clean headlights. 
They're less than $10. ﻿

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
In theory, would it not be the most effective to use the bugspray method 
along with your clearcoat method you posted?

I figure it would work like this:

1. Use Bug Spray Method to quickly clean off Oxidation and excess plastic 
from normal wear and tear.
2. After allowing headlight enough drying time(since the plastic begins to 
melt and become tacky) run a wet sand of 1000/2000 Grit to soften any 
orange peel that the melted plastic may have produced.
3. Isopropyl Alcohol cleanse and Dry
4. Spray clear coat(3 - 5 layers, if doing 5 layers use 2k grit light wet 
sand to soften any blemishes from amatur spraying)
5. ???
6.Profit

what do you guys think? Would this be the fastest most effective method for 
restoration or do you think the Chemicals in the bugspry, Isopropyl 
Alcohol, and/or Clear COat would have some od reaction and damage the 
Plastic materials?﻿
comments.author: Moonajuana

comments.text:
+Moonajuana Definitely keep me posted! I am curious about the long term 
effects!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+ChrisFix sounds legit. I used your wet sand method on one lens and tried 
my theory out on the other to see how quickly it will peel or if there are 
any visible differences. Hopefully the clearcoated bug spray method works 
well enough to last atleast 6 months. If so I'll label it a success. Your 
wet sanded clear coat method is more logical and the adherence of the clear 
coat was much more obvious than when trying to clearcoat the smoothed, bug 
sprayed side. Well see how each holds up over time.
comments.author: Moonajuana

comments.text:
+Moonajuana You would think that would be a good method but it isnt 
unfortunately. You do not want the lens to be smooth and the bug spray will 
cause the clear coat to bubble if you didnt get all of it off. You want to 
have scratches and follow the 400-600-2000 exactly like in this video. The 
600 grit puts deep enough scratches into the surface of the lens while the 
2000 light sand, cuts any surface roughness off. This allows for the clear 
coat to adhere properly so it wont peel in a year. If you make it smooth, 
the clear coat wont grab onto anything and it will peel. You can also have 
a problem with the paint running.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:

as you mentioned in another one of your videos?﻿

comments.text:
Is the DEET really melting the plastic, or is it melting the clear coat on 
the headlight.  If it's melting the clear coat, then couldn't you use the 
DEET to get all the old clear coat off (which is what I think was still 
tacky on your video) and then reapply clear coat or wax?﻿
comments.author: J Lo

comments.text:
+J Lo The DEET melts the plastic (and probably the clear coat). You do not 
want to buff the lens smooth anyhow. You want to have scratches and follow 
the 400-600-2000 exactly like in my headlight restoration video. The 600 
grit puts deep enough scratches into the surface of the lens while the 2000 
light sand, cuts any surface roughness off. This allows for the clear coat 
to adhere properly so it wont peel in a year. If you make it smooth, the 
clear coat wont grab onto anything and it will peel. You can also have a 
problem with the paint running.  Good thinking though!

half a day, away from moisture such as rain or dew.﻿
